Award.AwardTitle: MRI: acquisition of a gas chromatograph isotope ratio mass spectrometer for compound-specific isotope analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the acquisition of a gas chromatograph coupled to an isotope-ratio mass spectrometer (GC-IRMS) at Syracuse University (SU). GC-IRMS systems permit the analysis of stable isotopic ratios of hydrogen, carbon, and nitrogen in particular classes of organic materials ranging from waxes to amino acids to synthetic organic compounds. By isolating the isotopic signature of a single compound type with known pathways of synthesis, deposition, and degradation, GC-IRMS instrumentation allows us to link isotopic signals to particular chemical, physical, or biological processes. This instrument will therefore enable a broad group of users at SU to generate data that addresses questions of pressing social importance in a variety of fields. For instance, hydrogen isotopic analyses of lipid compounds produced by terrestrial plants can quantify paleoclimatic changes in rainfall. These data can then be used to evaluate the skill of climate models and hone our understanding of the reliability of future projections from these models. Analysis of nitrogen and carbon isotopes in amino acids also have the potential to advance our understanding of ocean ecosystem responses to both past and current global change. The instrument also serves an important educational function, providing undergraduate and graduate students with training in laboratory and analytical skills directly transferrable to STEM careers. Additionally, the GC-IRMS will support ongoing efforts to create summer internship opportunities for underserved K-12 and community college students, providing direct exposure to future career pathways in STEM fields.

GC-IRMS techniques combine the chromatographic resolution provided through GC with the precise isotopic measurements provided by mass spectrometry. This type of instrumentation will support ongoing NSF-funded research in paleoclimatology, ecology, and biogeochemistry. For instance, the presence of a GC-IRMS at SU will enable hydrogen isotopic analyses of terrestrial leaf waxes, which will be used to reconstruct monsoon dynamics during past warm intervals in Earth history. Moreeover, nitrogen and carbon isotopic analyses of baleen and carbonate shell-bound organic matter will support reconstructions of trophic webs in marine ecosystems. Additional users at SU and affiliated institutions will use compound-specific isotopic methods to interrogate the controls on the growth of freshwater microbialites, the transformation of pollutants in fluvial systems, and the structure and function of multi-trophic interactions in terrestrial ecosystems. The GC-IRMS therefore fulfills a major gap in research infrastructure at Syracuse University and will support the continuation as well as the growth of cutting-edge research across a variety of disciplines of Earth Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the purchase of a new gas chromatograph stable isotope mass spectrometer (GC-IRMS), and the development of a new facility for the study of ratios of isotopes of light elements (hydrogen, carbon, and nitrogen) in organic molecules, at Syracuse University (SU). GC-IRMS instrumentation facilitates compound-specific isotope analysis, whereby a given isotopic signal can be tied to a specific type of molecule with a known pathway of synthesis, transport, and degradation. For instance, hydrogen isotopes in leaf waxes provide a unique lens on regional rainfall changes over geologic time, carbon isotopes in algal lipids can help us reconstruct ancient carbon dioxide levels, and nitrogen isotopes in amino acids can shed light on food webs. GC-IRMS facilities therefore have the potential to yield insights into the fundamental processes that govern Earth's atmosphere, ocean, and biosphere.  The new instrument was purchased in 2020, and lab renovations and installation occurred in late 2021. The instrument has been in constant use since installation, apart from planned downtime for maintenance and repair tasks, all of which are handled by the PIs and staff of the facility.

 

The new isotope facility augments existing SU facilities for the extraction and quantification of organic materials, as well as facilities the analysis of stable isotopes in bulk organic matter. Facilitated by the new instrument from this award, Principal Investigators Bhattacharya and Junium now run the Joint Organic Geochemistry group at Syracuse University, overseeing a facility that supports a network of users and collaborators across Syracuse University, regional universities, and national and international scientists. This award supported measurements associated at least 4 federally or privately funded projects that probed past atmospheric dynamics and rainfall during past warm climates, the links between humans and environments in the archaeological record, and deeper time carbon cycling. In some cases, this work has yielded insights that are directly applicable to efforts to adapt to rainfall changes  in a warming world.

 

The facility has also been key in enhancing teaching and training at Syracuse University, supporting the work of a technician, a postdoctoral scholar, five graduate students, four undergraduate students, and a high school intern. All participants have received training in laboratory and analytical skills that are directly transferrable to STEM careers. The facility has also supported educational experiences for both PI’s outreach efforts with programs that support the recruitment and retention of underrepresented groups in STEM fields (e.g. the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation, and the Strategic Undergraduate STEM Talent Acceleration Initiative (SUSTAIN) at Syracuse University).
